TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}
TEXT.source: told by Giłgiław of Vałulu village

S.FORM: aitsu a ngatsi maretimałimałi a papungadan.
aico a ngaci maretimaljimalji a papongadan.
S.TRANSL: Snails are known by various names.

S.FORM: azua zuma nu qałan ḍułi aya; azua zuma nu qałan ngatsingatsi aya; azua zuma nu qałan tsirat aya.
azoa zoma no qaljan drolji aya; azoa zoma no qaljan ngacingaci aya; azoa zoma no qaljan cirat aya.
S.TRANSL: Some villages call them ḍułi, some ngatsingatsi, some tsirat.

S.FORM: aitsu a ngatsi selapay nu napesakuyakuya aravats nu tja patsunan.
aico a ngaci selapay no napesakoyakoya aravac no tja paconan.
S.TRANSL: Snails are extremely unpleasant to look at;

S.FORM: łakua sanguaq aravats nu tja kanen.
ljakoa sangoaq aravac no tja kanen.
S.TRANSL: but they are very tasty to eat.

S.FORM: a sisan kakanenan tja alapen azua seti sakamaya, sa tja senavi tua qavu a seman lialiaw, tua sika sualapan nazua djarayadjayadjay, sana tja qirqiri tua ławław, sa tja tau'iyu-i, sa tja djamayan.
a sisan kakanenan tja alapen azoa seti sakamaya, sa tja senavi toa qavo a seman lialiaw, toa sika soalapan nazoa djarayadjayadjay, sana tja qirqiri toa ljawljaw, sa tja tao'iyo-i, sa tja djamayan.
S.TRANSL: When we are going to prepare them to eat, we take the meat only and clean it many times over with ash/lime to get rid of the stickiness; them we fry them in oil, add soya sauce, and eat them as a side dish.

S.FORM: łakua inika amin a san djamayin; nanguaq uta a tsavuin tua ragrag tua sutjaw.
ljakoa inika amin a san djamayin; nangoaq ota a cavoin toa ragrag toa sotjaw.
S.TRANSL: But they are not only eaten as a side dish; they are also good wrapped up with pounded dry taro or peanuts.
We certainly lick our lips after eating them.

S.FORM: qau aitsu a ngatsi ika tjen a pakakeḍikeḍi nu malap itjen.
qao aico a ngaci ika tjen a pakakedrikedri no malap itjen.
S.TRANSL: We don’t just get a few snails.

S.FORM: mekeḍi aravats nu tja san kakanenen; saka nu łemliaw itjen sekuletj itjen.
mekedri aravac no tja san kakanenen; saka no ljemliaw itjen sekoletj itjen.
S.TRANSL: They go away to nothing when we cook them; so we get lots in order to have enough to eat.
